sub_topic: Prove that the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself.
message_1: Let A be a set containing 3 elements. What is the size of the power set of A, and how does this compare to the size of the original set A? Show that the size of the power set is always greater than the size of the original set.
message_2:
Let A be a set containing 3 elements, say A = {a, b, c}. The power set of A, denoted as P(A), is the set of all possible subsets of A, including the empty set and the set A itself.

P(A) = {∅, {a}, {b}, {c}, {a, b}, {a, c}, {b, c}, {a, b, c}}

The size of the power set of A, |P(A)|, is the number of elements in P(A). In this case, |P(A)| = 8.

Now let's compare the size of the power set of A to the size of the original set A. The size of the original set A, |A|, is 3 (since it has 3 elements). Therefore, |P(A)| > |A|, as 8 > 3.

To show that the size of the power set is always greater than the size of the original set, let's consider a set B with n elements. The size of the power set of B, |P(B)|, is given by the formula 2^n (since each element can either be included or excluded from a subset). 

Since n ≥ 0, we have 2^n ≥ 1 (as 2^0 = 1). Therefore, 2^n > n for all n ≥ 0. This means that the size of the power set of any set is always greater than the size of the original set.
